review_title: Wonderful people, structure is a work in progress
pros:
The people you get to work with are fantastic. GFU is a faith-based organization, allowing for a lot of conversations and support related to spirituality (prayer, ministry, etc.). Those in Administration, Student Life, and Academic Affairs want to be here and are committed to creating a great experience for their colleagues and areas served (students, families, alumni, external connections).
There is a lot of support from your supervisors to develop and grow in your position and as a person.
cons:
Due to size and budget (this is a non-profit), there isn't a lot of room for advancement in your position; most move to other departments, or leave and possible come back. Salary is low (again, non-profit). The Benefits package takes a lot of your paycheck as well (just under a third). A lot of issues with Human Resources making mistakes on documents and missing critical details, so always check everything twice. 
If you are salaried work life balance is difficult as the cultural norm is to work more hours (avg. 45/wk). 
You will wear a few different hats in your role because of limited resources, which can be overwhelming and add to frustration with working extra hours. 
Too data heavy - management struggles to consider the values and purpose of certain activities when they get too focused on numbers.

pros:
-If you love students, you'll love the culture here. Professors are expected to take a vested interest in the growth and development of the students in their courses and in their majors.
-The undergraduate campus in Newberg is beautiful
-The benefits are acceptable
cons:
-Salary is low, but what do you expect for a Christian school? 
-Though there is heavy emphasis on delivering on the "Be Known" promise, there is also a high expectation for committee work, research, and publication. More bricks, less straw.
-Faculty-Administration relationship is tense, bordering on adversarial. In the decade I've been there, the President's annual message has not changed: "The landscape of higher education is changing. Innovation is a must. It can't cost more. We are doing okay now, but need to make changes for the future."
-There is no definition for what "innovation" looks like. It feels like everyone is being asked to throw ideas against the wall and see what sticks.
-The university is closing non-professional programs (ie the liberal arts disciplines like English, History, Philosophy) but aggressively hiring and growing the "high barrier" money-makers like Engineering, Nursing, and a slew of medical grad programs. It is simultaneously gutting general education requirements. 
-In 2-3 years, this university will basically be an expensive vo-tech school with some religion requirements bracketed on.

review_title: Doctoral student and TA for the flagship program of George Fox University: Graduate Department of Clinical Psychology
job_title: Teaching Assistant, Doctoral Student In GDCP in Newberg, OR
pros: Amazing professors to TA for. Doctoral students have unprecedented access to their professors via class time, office time, supervision, impromptu drop-in visits between classes and clinical work, and even regular invitations to professors' homes for social and professional events. As a TA, this dynamic is potentiated and as a result, selected students for TA assignments have real opportunities to glean even greater training from their supervisors in this capacity. I loved my time at GFU in the GDCP and recommend this program to anyone who wants to take advantage of the stellar line up of locally and nationally well-recognized professors who not only instruct but also have simultaneous clinical practices. There's a reason why this program is APA-accredited and rarely struggles to place interns while many other programs struggle annually.
cons: I struggle to name a "con" because if students care to change something in the program, they are never stifled to be a part of the change they request.

pros: Pleasant working environment with opportunities to develop relationships with peers and students. We get to see positive results because of the work we do here educating students in a faith-based environment.

pros: The faculty of George Fox University excel at their jobs. As is typical of small, private schools, they are there to teach and mentor students. That is their desire. Students receive an excellent education from dedicated faculty.
cons: It is said, it's not what you know but who you know. In my almost 30 years in education, this has never been more obvious than at George Fox University. Unqualified, under-educated people are routinely hired and promoted at this school. As a result, there is a level of incompetence that I have not seen elsewhere. The administration has also fallen victim to surrounding itself with people who refuse to tell them they wear no clothes. Surprisingly, I do not think this has yet to affect the quality of education that students receive. It has affected the quality of the work place for many hard-working, dedicated employees. There is a lot of inequality and little transparency. For a Christian organization, there is also a lot of questionable actions by people in leadership.

pros: In general, the faculty here tend to be more progressive, while the board of directors trends fairly conservative. The office I worked in (residence life) went out of its way to respect the work-life balance of its employees. I found that they were also willing to listen to complaints and concerns, and consistently worked with employees to establish a healthy work culture.
cons: The juxtaposition between the general feelings of the faculty and the policies outlined by the directors can occasionally create a complicated and uncomfortable work culture. Also, the school saw some turnover as a result of this, with several employees feeling like the school was somewhat hostile toward their social and religious positions.

review_title: Has increasingly become a business versus the "be known" University motto
pros:
HR calls it a job, we call it in ministry! If you're interested in working at a small Christian University where you can share your faith with students and colleagues and do ministry as your career, then this is a good place to be. GFU has a small town, small university feel where people know your name and care for you.

If you work at the undergraduate level, many of the administrators live nearby in Newberg or surrounding areas and are involved in extracurricular activities such as the sporting events. The seminary is located in Tigard (on the edge of Portland), 30 mins from the main campus. The Willamette Valley is known as wine country with rolling hills, farms, and green green green everywhere!
cons:
GFU has gone from a very small community oriented University into a business model in which they have been hiring "J" Myers-Briggs personnel that focus on the logical facts and over the years have continued to hire people who fit the business venture. They are letting go of the "P" employees who bring the soft side to the motto "Be Known" that they promote to students and families. 

Financially, the pay is low due to being a nonprofit organization.
